subject: Re: [junit] How to test private methods in a class.
msgSnippet: ... Public interfaces. Public factories. Package-private implementations, in the package of the factory. Tests in the same package as the class they test.
messageBody:
Elliotte Harold wrote:
> That's basically correct in general. The problem is that Java doesn't
> have a real distinction between public and published. If it's public,
> then it's published. Given that we're working in Java (especially Java 5
> and earlier; things may get better in Java 6) we have to live with this.
> In another language, it might be different; but in Java everything
> that's public is published, whether you want it to be or not.

Public interfaces.

Public factories.

Package-private implementations, in the package of the factory.

Tests in the same package as the class they test.

Also, for the purposes of JavaDoc at least, you can exclude particular
packages. Packaging into an API and runtime jars also helps here.

In other words, there are ways around this limitation, if they are
important enough for you.
